--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Cedric Beust" <cbeust@g...> wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of
> Robert Watkins
>  
> > Well, personally, I've got no problem with using Method 
> > Objects, so the idea of passing parameters in as constructors 
> > isn't a big deal.
> 
> It's not a big deal but imagine a class that has ten test methods
and each
> of them needs a different parameter.  Are you going to pass all these
> parameters in the constructor, store them in a separate field and
then have
> each method use the particular field they need?

No, I would have seperate test classes in this instance. Yes, it's a
limitation, but only a mild one. Most likely, particularly if I'm
writing a suite() method to call the constructors anyway, I'd making
these test classes private inner classes so that I don't end up with a
cluttered source tree.

> > The idea that I have to have tests run in a particular 
> > order to get repeatability strikes me as odd as well
> 
> Why would you need to do that?  We are just talking about being able
to pass
> parameters to test methods.  The order in which these methods are
invoked is
> irrelevant...  right?

No.

First, yes, I was shifting the argument a bit to counter-inituitive
behaviour. But I was just following you there.

Secondly, if it was irrelevant, you wouldn't have the "requires"
annotation (I forget exactly the semantics) in TestNG; the purpose of
that annotation is to ensure that _known_ requirements are done first,
not just to ensure that required functionality is working, but to set
up known state.

Thirdly, if you've got methods in a class that can leave state behind,
then you've got an implicit ordering from side effects. As I said, I
find it counter intuitive that I have to be careful about side effects
in my test cases. End of digression... though I'll be happy to
continue if we spawn a new thread.
 
> > Have you thought about an option like this?
> > 
> > @ParameterList({ "oneName" }, {"anotherName"}, {"aThirdName"}) 
> > @Test public void testSingleString(String firstName) { ...
> > }
> 
> You mean defining the various values in the source itself?

As an option. Not the only option, but one available under the right
circumstances.
 
> No, I hadn't thought about it, but it's an intriguing idea.  My first
> reaction is that it would force me to recompile my source file
whenever I
> want to change or add a parameter, but I can see how a JUnit user
wouldn't
> mind that :-)

Or an Eclipse user... after all, it will recompile when I save. 

The main advantage here is that if you only got a few interesting
cases to look for, you can keep them with the source code.
Furthermore, once I finished building the test, it's not like I'm
jumping back in and editing it a lot anyway.

> > The vast majority of times I want a parameterised test, I 
> > don't really want a _lot_ of parameters, but I'm not sure I'd 
> > want to muck around with defining the parameters in the XML 
> > either;
> 
> Fair enough, I'm open to hearing suggestions, but I really think
that you
> need a way to be able to invoke the same test class with different
values
> for parameters.  How would you like to do that?

Annotations in the code _as an option_ works. Supplementing the
existing XML and programatic techniques.
 
> Most users simply invoke TestNG from ant or from the command line
and they
> never write a single line of XML.

Unless they start doing something fancy... ;) Of course, JUnit starts
asking you to grow beyond the default behaviour as well, so that's a
bit of a fallacious argument.

Robert.
